biblStruct.note: received August 3, 2018; accepted October 1, 2018. Manuscript received in final form October 7, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This brief examines the problem of attitude tracking control with prescribed performance guarantees for a spacecraft subjected to actuator faults and input saturation. To pursue this, the open-loop tracking error dynamics with certain designerspecified performance constraints is first transformed into an equivalent "state-constrained" one, via an error transformation; furthermore, the resulting dynamics is augmented with a dynamic system, which is tactfully constructed to ensure that the control input satisfies the magnitude limits. Subsequently, a robust faulttolerant controller is developed by using a low-pass filter and an auxiliary system in conjunction with adaptive backstepping design. It is shown that the control algorithm developed not only achieves the stable attitude tracking with prescribed behavioral metrics but also guarantees the boundedness of all the closed-loop signals. Finally, simulation results are given to evaluate the efficacy of the proposed scheme.

behavior, without taking into account the transient performance metrics including the convergence rate and overshoot. On the other side, the system responses resulted from applying those methods are largely hinged on the control gains selection. As a matter of fact, guaranteeing transient and steady-state performance bounds specified a prior by the designer is a practical design aspect that is difficult to be incorporated into the closed-loop design but is nonetheless crucial to ensure mission success via a nontime-consuming control gains selection. Fortunately, Bechlioulis and Rovithakis [5] creatively proposed the concepts and techniques of prescribed performance control. Later, this control paradigm was applied extensively in various classes of nonlinear systems to obtain guaranteed performance bounds [6]- [10] (just to name a few). In particular, Zhou et al. [9] and Hu et al. [10] exploited such a promising technique to explore robust controller design in the context of spacecraft attitude tracking.

In real spacecraft applications, another important aspect that deserves special attention is actuator faults. The lessons learned from the mishaps that were recorded and analyzed in [11] indicate that actuator faults may result in malfunctions of the attitude control system (ACS), which might further result in aborting the given mission. On-orbit spacecraft would benefit from the inclusion of the capability of fault tolerance against actuator faults in the attitude control subsystem to enhance reliability. Fault-tolerant control (FTC) is an effective technique to tackle actuator faults in nonlinear systems. As summarized in [12], the existing methods for FTC systems design can in general be classified into two types, namely, passive and active FTCs. In this brief, we take efforts on developing a passive fault-tolerant controller for spacecraft attitude tracking, due to the advantages of passive FTC with respect to the active one in terms of structural complexity and real-time property. In this respect, thus far, numerous control strategies have been provided in the literature (see, indicatively, [13]- [18] and references therein). In addition, the input saturation is also an issue of practical importance. It often drastically degrades system performance, and may give rise to undesirable inaccuracy or, even worse, lead to instability. Even though a significant amount of research has been undertaken on spacecraft attitude control design with consideration of actuator saturation (see [14], [16], [19]- [23] and references therein), the majority of existing results may end up with unsatisfactory control performance in the presence of actuator faults.

Despite recent advances in fault-tolerant prescribed performance control [6], [24]- [26], it is still a challenging problem on how to guarantee prescribed performance in the presence of actuator faults (especially total failures) and input saturation. Hence, it is an interesting and meaningful topic to investigate the problem of attitude tracking control with guaranteed tracking metrics for spacecraft subject to both actuator faults and saturation, which motivates the main results in this brief. The major contributions of this brief are summarized as follows.

1) A novel dynamic system is artfully constructed to generate the control input signals that naturally fulfil the magnitude limits by designing an intermediate control law. Theoretically, it is relatively easy to formulate the intermediate control law, hence bypassing the difficulty in designing a saturated control law for the commanded control input immediately. 2) A robust FTC algorithm is synthesized by employing a low-pass filter and an auxiliary dynamic system in conjunction with adaptive backstepping design, which achieves attitude tracking with prescribed behavioral metrics, despite the presence of exogenous disturbances, actuator faults (especially total failures), and input saturation. Notation: I 3 is the identity matrix of dimension 3 × 3, and || • || denotes either the Euclidean vector norm or the induced matrix norm. Given any matrix A, we denote by λ min (A) and λ max (A) its minimum and maximum eigenvalues, respectively. In addition, we denote the notation (•) × ∈ 3×3 as a skew-symmetric matrix.

div.head: A. Spacecraft Attitude Tracking Dynamics
div.p: In this brief, we consider the attitude tracking problem of a spacecraft. Within this context, three Cartesian frames (denoted by I, B, and R) are defined to describe the attitude motion of the spacecraft. Specifically, I denotes an inertial frame, while B and R correspond to the body-fixed and desired reference frames, respectively. Suppose that full knowledge including the attitude and angular velocity of the spacecraft is exactly available through onboard measurement sensors.
The open-loop tracking error dynamics are [13] qev = 1 2 (q × ev + q e4 I 3 )ω e and qe4 = -
div.formula: 1 2 q T ev ω e (1
J ωe = -ω × J ω + J(ω × e Cω d -C ωd ) + τ + T d (2)
div.p: where q e := col(q ev , q e4 ) ∈ 4 is the unit quaternion describing the relative attitude orientation of the spacecraft in B with respect to R, and satisfies q T ev q ev + q 2 e4 = 1, ω ∈ 3 is the angular velocity of the spacecraft expressed in B, ω r ∈ 3 is the desired angular velocity expressed in R, ω e = ω -Cω r is the angular velocity error, the direction cosine matrix C ∈ SO(3) is defined by C = (q 2 e4 -q T ev q ev )I 3 +2q ev q T ev -2q e4 q × ev , and J ∈ 3×3 is the inertia matrix of the spacecraft. In (2), τ ∈ 3 and T d ∈ 3 denote the control torque and the external disturbance, respectively.

Suppose that the matrix 0.5(q × ev + q e4 I 3 ) denoted hereafter as Q is invertible, and we define P = Q -1 . To facilitate the control design and generalize our theoretical findings, we transform the tracking error dynamics (1) and ( 2) into an Euler-Lagrange (EL) equation by following the exposition in [27]:
div.formula: M * qev + C * qev + P T H = P T τ + P T T d (3
div.p: where M * = P T J P, C * = P T J Ṗ -P T ( J P qev ) × P, and H = ω × e J(Cω r )+(Cω r ) × J (Cω r +ω e )-J(ω × e Cω r -C ωr ). The derived dynamics (3) has some algebraic properties that are useful for the subsequent control synthesis and stability analysis.
Property 1: The inertia-like matrix M * is symmetric and positive definite, and can be lower and upper bounded by (the proof is straightforward and omitted here)
div.formula: λ min ( J ) P x 2 ≤ x T M * x ≤ λ max ( J) P x 2 ∀x ∈ 3 . (4)
div.p: Property 2 [27]: Matrix Ṁ * -2C * is skew-symmetric, and x T ( Ṁ * -2C * )x = 0 for any vector x ∈ 3 . Property 3: The two norms of the matrix P can be calculated by P = 2/|q e4 | (see the Appendix).
Remark 1: To ensure that Q is invertible, which is in fact a necessary condition for the validity of the EL equation (3), the following condition must hold:

In order to guarantee that (5) remains valid, not only the initial condition needs to be restricted such that q e4 (0) = 0, but also the subsequent control scheme is required to maintain q e4 (t) = 0 for all t > 0. However, most of the existing literature, like [22] and [28], do not offer rigorous theoretical guarantees for the latter condition. In this brief, we shall provide a solution to fill this gap.

div.head: B. Actuator Fault Modes
div.p: It is common practice to endow a spacecraft with more than three torque actuators for redundancy and robustness concerns. To describe actuator faults, the control input of the system (3) is further expressed as τ = D(Eu + ū) (6) where D ∈ 3×n (n ≥ 3) is the actuator distribution matrix that characterizes the influence of each torque actuator on angular acceleration of the vehicle; E = diag(e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e n ) with 0 ≤ e i ≤ 1 (i = 1, 2, . . . , n) denotes the actuation effectiveness matrix, while u ∈ n and ū ∈ n denote the commanded control input to be designed and unexpected deviation faults, respectively. Under such an expression, the following common fault modes can be considered for each torque actuator [28], [29]: F1) partial loss of effectiveness; F2) failure to response to control signal; F3) null and continuous bias; and F4) locking. Note that the condition (7) needs to be satisfied for all fault scenarios that are under consideration, since otherwise the ACS becomes an under-actuated one [15], for which arbitrary attitude tracking along all three degrees of freedom becomes physically challenging
div.formula: rank(D E) = 3. (7
div.p: Lemma 1 [28]: Suppose that matrix D is of full-row rank (by proper placement of the actuators on the spacecraft). Then, for all fault scenarios under consideration, DED T remains positive definite if and only if the condition (7) holds.

div.head: C. Input Saturation
div.p: Suppose here that each component of the control input signal u is constrained by a separate maximum magnitude u imax . To this end, inspired by Wen et al. [30], the following dynamic system is tactfully constructed to generate the control input u:
div.formula: u = -κ u + g(u c ) (8
div.p: where
div.formula: κ > 0, g(u c ) = [g(u c1 ), g(u c2 ), . . . , g(u cn )] T with u c = [u c1 , u c2 , . . . , u cn ] T (u c (0) = 0)
div.p: an auxiliary intermediate signal that is yet to be designed, and g(u ci ) (i = 1, 2, . . . , n) is defined by the smooth hyperbolic tangent function
div.formula: g(u ci ) = u * ci tanh u ci u * ci = u * ci e u ci /u * ci -e -u ci /u * ci e u ci /u * ci + e -u ci /u * ci (9
div.p: in which u * ci represents the maximum allowable value of the i th entry of the vector g(u c ).
Proposition 1: Consider the system described in ( 8), if we choose u * ci = κu i max , i = 1, 2, . . . , n, then the commanded control input u satisfies the magnitude limits
Proof: Solving the first-order differential equation ( 8) with zero initial condition yields
div.formula: u(t) = t 0 e -κ(t -τ ) g(u c )dτ. (10
div.p: Noting that |g(u ci )| ≤ u * ci (i = 1, 2, . . . , n) and 0 < e -κ(t -τ ) ≤ 1, we can get from (10) that
div.formula: |u i (t)| ≤ u * ci t 0 e -κ(t -τ ) dτ = u * ci /κ (1 -e -κt ) ≤ u * ci κ. (11
div.p: Due to u * ci = κu i max , it can be readily concluded from (11) that |u i (t)| ≤ u i max , i = 1, 2, . . . , n, and this completes the proof.

Remark 2: Inspecting (11) reveals that u i (t) is actually upper bounded by a time-varying limit u imax (1 -e -κt ), whose value increases from 0 to u imax at an exponentially decreasing rate with time t. It is generally preferable to select a large κ, so that the actuators can provide acceptable transient performance for the initial stage of the attitude tracking maneuvers.

div.head: III. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: The objective of this brief is to develop an inertia-free FTC scheme for spacecraft attitude tracking, which guarantees stable attitude tracking with prescribed performance, despite the presence of exogenous disturbances, actuator faults, and input saturation.
It is sufficient to achieve the goal by guaranteeing [10] P li (t) < q evi (t) < P ui (t
with P ui (t) and P li (t) defined by
div.formula: P ui (t) = k si ρ ui (t) + (1 -k si )k oi ρ li (t) P li (t) = -[k si k oi ρ li (t) + (1 -k si )ρ ui (t)] (13
div.p: where k si and k oi , i = 1, 2, 3 are the design constants, whereas ρ j i (t), j ∈{l, u}, and i = 1, 2, 3 are the performance functions of the form ρ j i (t) = (ρ j i0 -ρ j i∞ )e -l ji t + ρ j i∞ (14) where ρ j i0 , ρ j i∞ , and l j i are the positive constants. It should be noted that ρ j i0 = ρ j i (0) needs to be given such that (12) holds at t = 0. The desired transient and steady-state behavioral metrics on the tracking error q evi (t) can be characterized a prior by selecting proper performance functions ρ j i (t), j ∈ {l, u}, as well as the design constants k si and k oi . Please refer to [10] for more details about the related parameter selections.
To embody the desired performance bounds imposed by ( 12) into the closed-loop design, the following error transformation is performed:
div.formula: ε i (t) = 2q evi (t) -(P ui (t) + P li (t)) P ui (t) -P li (t) . (15
div.p: As stated in [10], achieving prescribed performance guarantees boils down to ensuring that the constraints |ε i (t)| < 1, i = 1, 2, 3, are never violated. An important caveat is that the case of q evi (0) = 0 requires the choice of k oi = 1.
Hereafter, we will drop the time argument t for brevity. Let us define x 1 = q ev , x 2 = qev , and 3) with ( 8) renders the following cascaded form:
div.formula: ε = [ε 1 , ε 2 , ε 3 ] T . Augmenting (
⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ ε = diag(1/(P ui -P li ))2x 2 -v, i = 1, 2, 3 M * ẋ2 + C * x 2 + P T H = P T D Eu + P T d u = -κ u + g(u c )(16)
div.p: where d = D ū + T d denotes the lumped disturbance vector.

div.head: IV. CONTROL DESIGN AND STABILITY ANALYSIS
div.p: At this point, we focus on the design of a robust faulttolerant controller for the augmented system described in (16), with the aim of guaranteeing the satisfaction of the constraints |ε i (t)| < 1, i = 1, 2, 3. To compensate the adverse effect arising from input saturation, we introduce the following auxiliary system [31]:
div.formula: ς = -k ς ς + u c and ς(0) = 0(17)
div.p: where ς ∈ n is the auxiliary state vector, u c = g(u c )u c is the deviation between the signals u c and g(u c ), and k ς > 0 is a design parameter. Inspired by Li et al. [32], the control law derivation is carried out by following the standard backstepping approach. To proceed, the following change of coordinates is made:
div.formula: z 1 = ε, z 2 = x 2 -x v , and z 3 = u --ς (18

Furthermore, we define the filtered error vector y = u v for analysis purpose.

[13], in what follows, we explore an adaptive control approach that is dependent on the following reasonable assumptions. 1) During the entire attitude operation, the inertia matrix J of the spacecraft remains unchanged (or varies slowly over time), but otherwise unknown owing to fuel consumptions, rotation of solar arrays, and onboard payload variations. 2) Both the external disturbance T d and the deviation fault ū are bounded, and there exists an unknown positive constant d m such that ||d|| ≤ d m . Solving (45) yields

Theorem 1: Consider the attitude tracking error system described in (1), ( 2), (6), and (8). Given any positive constant p, for all initial conditions lying in the compact set , the control law (40), implemented in conjunction with the auxiliary system (17), and the low-pass filter (19), can guarantee the following.
1) The resulted closed-loop system is semiglobally stable in the sense that all the internal signal variables are bounded, and, in particular, the transformed error z 1 (t) remains within the set
div.formula: Z 1 := {z 1 ∈ 3 : |z 1i | < 1, i = 1, 2, 3} for all time. 2) If the performance functions ρ ui (t), i = 1, 2, 3 are given such that ρ 2 u1 (0) + ρ 2 u2 (0) + ρ 2 u3 (0) < 1 holds
div.p: , then the condition (5) in Remark 1 remains valid all the time. Proof: With (45) and (46) in mind, we are ready to establish the following crucial results.

1) It can be easily concluded from (45) that V3 < 0 as long as V 3 > β 1 /a 1 . However, as the stability analysis is performed on the compact set , the resulted closed-loop system is in essence semiglobally stable. Equation (46) implies the boundedness of V 3 (t). Then, from the definition of
div.formula: V 3 , it can be concluded that V 1 is bounded. With V 1 bounded, it follows from (20) that |z 1 | = 1, i = 1, 2, 3
div.p: , from which we can refer that z 1 (t) remains within the set Z 1 for all time, due to z 1 (0) ∈ Z 1 . Furthermore, it is trivial to infer from the 2) By invoking 1), we know that z 1 (t) remains within the set Z 1 for all time, which implies that the attitude errors q evi (t), i = 1, 2, 3 evolve strictly along with the corresponding performance envelopes defined via (12). Furthermore, with the selection of ρ ui (t), i = 1, 2, 3 meeting the constraint ρ 2 u1 (0) + ρ 2 u2 (0) + ρ 2 u3 (0) < 1, we have q T ev q ev < ρ 2 u1 (0) + ρ 2 u2 (0) + ρ 2 u3 (0) < 1. Due to the normalization constraint of the quaternion, we further have
where is a positive constant. It can be thus claimed from (47) that q e4 (t) = 0 for all t ≥ 0. Hence, the condition (5) as stressed in Remark 1 is valid.

div.head: V. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, some simulation results are given to show the effectiveness of the proposed control algorithm. The satellite is assumed to be equipped with four reaction wheels mounted in a typical pyramid configuration for attitude maneuvers, as shown in Fig. 1. Moreover, it carries a space-borne surveillance radar instrument to monitor some high-priority areas. To accomplish the assigned mission, the satellite is required to track a desired attitude trajectory given in advance.

The physical parameters of the satellite are given in Table I. In the simulations, the desired attitude trajectory is described as a smooth rotation around each axis of R with desired angular velocity ω r = 0.573 × [cos(t/40), sin(t/30), and -cos(t/50)] T deg/s and initial attitude q r (0) = [0, 0, 0, 1] T . The external disturbance takes the same form as that simulated in [10]. The assigned mission triggers a range of requirements on the ACS of the satellite. In particular, it needs to achieve the attitude tracking with absolute pointing accuracy better than 1 min of arc and converge rate greater than the exponential exp(-0.1t) (which implies that in approximately 100 s, the attitude errors converge to the steady-state values). In addition, no overshoot is permitted for safety concern. To meet these requirements, the performance function parameters are listed in Table II. In addition, we take κ = 3 and u * ci = 1.5, i = 1, 2, 3, 4 for the dynamic system in (8), and choose k ς = 3 for the auxiliary system in (17). The filter time constant is taken as c = 0.01. The following control parameters are adopted:

The fault scenarios simulated are outlined as here as "IRAFTC") proposed in [13] is also simulated, and its design parameters are chosen here based on trial and error such that the IRAFTC and the controller proposed in this brief (denoted here as "AFPPC") have nearly identical settling times in the absence of actuator faults. The transformed error vector ε(t) is depicted in Fig. 2, where the embedded subplot provides detailed behaviors at the steady state. It can be observed that ε i (t) (i = 1, 2, 3) does not transgress the corresponding barriers at ε i (t) = ±1. This indicates that the attitude errors q evi (t), i = 1, 2, 3 are forced to evolve strictly along the performance bounds defined in (12), as clearly shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3 shows the attitude tracking errors for both controllers, along with the corresponding performance envelopes. As can be seen, the IRAFTC fails to guarantee prescribed tracking performance metrics, even though it achieves stable attitude tracking, whereas the AFPPC satisfies the prescribed performance in the presence of actuator faults. IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CONTROL SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY The response of ||ω e || is provided in Fig. 4, where the semilogarithmic scale is adopted to illustrate more clearly the comparision result. It can be seen that the AFPPC exhibits a smaller angular velocity error at the steady-state than the IRAFTC. The control input signals and the actual driving torques produced by the reaction wheels are shown in Fig. 5(a) for the AFPPC and in Fig. 5(b) for the IRAFTC. Obviously, both controllers fulfil the input magnitude limits and, in particular, the AFPPC satisfies the time-varying limit 0.5(1e -κt ), as discussed in Section II-C.

Overall, the designed controller successfully realizes attitude tracking with prescribed transient and steady-state performance bounds and a high degree of attitude stability, thus meeting a set of stringent requirements critical to mission success.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this brief, we have proposed a robust FTC scheme for spacecraft attitude tracking. Our approach achieves attitude tracking with prescribed behavioral metrics, despite the presence of external disturbances, actuator faults, and saturation; moreover, it does not resort to explicit knowledge of the inertia properties and a tricky selection of the control gains. Compared to the majority of existing results in spacecraft attitude tracking control problem, the proposed control algorithm possesses two appealing features: 1) it can account for actuator faults (including total failures in particular) and input saturation simultaneously, regardless of external disturbances and 2) it is user/designer friendly, due to the fact that the desired performance criteria are solely characterized by selecting performance functions. The future research efforts will be dedicated toward studying the effects of sensor measurement errors on the closed-loop performance.

div.head: APPENDIX PROOF OF PROPERTY 3
div.p: By simple matrix operations, we arrive at
div.formula: P T P = ( Q Q T ) -1 .
div.p: To derive the 2-norm of P, we first check the eigenvalues of matrix Q Q T by using MATLAB symbolic computations syms qe1 qe2 qe3 qe4 real; Q = 0.5 * [qe4 -qe3 qe2; qe3 qe4 -qe1; -qe2 qe1 qe4]; assumeAlso(qe1^2 + qe2^2 + qe3^2 + qe4^2 == 1); simplify(eig(Q * Q ));

Executing the above codes yields the eigenvalues of Q Q T , i.e., q 2 e4 /4, 1/4, and 1/4, from whose inverses we immediately get the maximum singular value of P as 2/|q e4 |, due to |q e4 | ≤ 1. It thus follows that || P|| = 2/|q e4 |.
This completes the proof.

Noting that ρ j i (t), j ∈{l, u}, and i = 1, 2, 3 are exponentially decaying functions with bounded initial values as well as nonzero steady-state values, we further draw the conclusion that the virtual control law x v is bounded. This observation leads to the boundedness of x 2 due to x 2 = z 2 + x v . According to Property 3 and the fact that q 2 e4 > with a positive constant (which will be clearly seen in the second bullet point), it is a straightforward matter to check from || ω e || = ||Px 2 || ≤ ||P||||x 2 || that ω e is bounded. Apart from the above argument, we note that b = b -b with b a constant vector, implying that b is bounded. Similarly, we can infer that γ is bounded. Inspecting(32) and the definition of reveals that u v is bounded, which indicates the boundedness of [see(19)]. At this point, it is concluded from Proposition 1,(17), and (40) that ς , u, and hence u c are bounded. In summary, all closed-loop signals are bounded, and the constraints imposed on the transformed error ε(t) are not violated. 2) By invoking 1), we know that z 1 (t) remains within the set Z 1 for all time, which implies that the attitude errors q evi (t), i = 1, 2, 3 evolve strictly along with the corresponding performance envelopes defined via(12). Furthermore, with the selection of ρ ui (t), i = 1, 2, 3 meeting the constraint ρ 2 u1 (0) + ρ 2 u2 (0) + ρ 2 u3 (0) < 1, we have q T ev q ev < ρ 2 u1 (0) + ρ 2 u2 (0) + ρ 2 u3 (0) < 1.
